intro: Rubus gallaecicus, commonly known as the Galician raspberry, is a species of bramble native to the Iberian Peninsula. It is characterized by its trailing growth habit and produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically red when mature. The plant has pinnately compound leaves with serrated margins and produces white or pink flowers in the spring. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks. The berries are edible and have a tart flavor, making them a valuable resource in local ecosystems.
